erlref.modulesummary: Functions for reading comment lines from Erlang source code.

description.p: Functions for reading comment lines from Erlang source code.

func.name: file(FileName::filename() (see module file)) -> [Comment]
func.fsummary: Extracts comments from an Erlang source code file.

desc.p: Extracts comments from an Erlang source code file. Returns a list of entries representing multi-line comments, listed in order of increasing line-numbers. For each entry, Text is a list of strings representing the consecutive comment lines in top-down order; the strings contain all characters following (but not including) the first comment-introducing % character on the line, up to (but not including) the line-terminating newline.

Furthermore, Line is the line number and Column the left column of the comment (i.e., the column of the comment-introducing % character). Indent is the indentation (or padding), measured in character positions between the last non-whitespace character before the comment (or the left margin), and the left column of the comment. Line and Column are always positive integers, and Indentation is a nonnegative integer.
Evaluation exits with reason {read, Reason} if a read error occurred, where Reason is an atom corresponding to a Posix error code; see the module file(3) for details.

func.name: string(Text::string()) -> [Comment]
func.fsummary: Extracts comments from a string containing Erlang source code.

desc.p: Extracts comments from a string containing Erlang source code. Except for reading directly from a string, the behaviour is the same as for file/1.

func.name: scan_lines(Text::string()) -> [CommentLine]
func.fsummary: Extracts individual comment lines from a source code string.

desc.p: Extracts individual comment lines from a source code string. Returns a list of comment lines found in the text, listed in order of decreasing line-numbers, i.e., the last comment line in the input is first in the resulting list. Text is a single string, containing all characters following (but not including) the first comment-introducing % character on the line, up to (but not including) the line-terminating newline. For details on Line, Column and Indent, see file/1.

func.name: join_lines(Lines::[CommentLine]) -> [Comment]
func.fsummary: Joins individual comment lines into multi-line comments.

desc.p: Joins individual comment lines into multi-line comments. The input is a list of entries representing individual comment lines, in order of decreasing line-numbers; see scan_lines/1 for details. The result is a list of entries representing multi-line comments, still listed in order of decreasing line-numbers, but where for each entry, Text is a list of consecutive comment lines in order of increasing line-numbers (i.e., top-down).
